repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This exposes cjson's `encode_escape_forward_slash ` option to the user, but without global side-effects.
I want to encode a nice human-readable JSON files in my plugin, but escaping every slash (for example in file paths) makes this impossible. 

The only use case I know for forward slash escaping is preventing HTML injections (eg. injecting `</script>` closing tag), so in context of typical nvim plugin it does not matter. (that's why escaping it in JSON is optional)

Probably best reviewed commit by commit:
- `refactor(json): add json encode context type` 
  - Extracts common encoding state to a `json_encode_t` struct (this matches what `json_parse_t` does)
- `feat(json): add call local version of escape_forward_slash`
  - Makes use of the new context struct to implement new `escape_forward_slash` option

comment_data.body:
probably makes sense to also test decode()? And, what should decode() do if it sees `\\/` ?

    decode(encode(...))
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -152,6 +152,23 @@ describe('vim.json.encode()', function()
     clear()
   end)
 
+  it('dumps strings with escaped slash', function()
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/')]]))
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/', {})]]))
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/', { __invalid_key = true })]]))
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/', { escape_forward_slash = true })]]))

comment_data.body: all these tests should be in 1 test, especially to check that the option does not affect anything globally (and there should be an explicit check for that)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -152,6 +152,23 @@ describe('vim.json.encode()', function()
     clear()
   end)
 
+  it('dumps strings with escaped slash', function()
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/')]]))
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/', {})]]))
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/', { __invalid_key = true })]]))
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/', { escape_forward_slash = true })]]))
+  end)
+
+  it('dumps strings without escaped slash', function()
+    eq('"Test/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/', { escape_forward_slash = false })]]))
+    eq(
+      '"Test/"',
+      exec_lua(
+        [[return vim.json.encode('Test/', { __invalid_key = true, escape_forward_slash = false })]]

comment_data.body:
unnecessarily verbose

```suggestion
                • escape_slash: (boolean) When true, escapes `/`
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -812,11 +812,14 @@ vim.json.decode({str}, {opts})                             *vim.json.decode()*
     Return: ~
         (`any`)
 
-vim.json.encode({obj})                                     *vim.json.encode()*
+vim.json.encode({obj}, {opts})                             *vim.json.encode()*
     Encodes (or "packs") Lua object {obj} as JSON in a Lua string.
 
     Parameters: ~
-      • {obj}  (`any`)
+      • {obj}   (`any`)
+      • {opts}  (`table<string,any>?`) Options table with keys:

comment_data.body: Added two cases for that, decode seems to be up to standard. It decodes `\\/` as `/`.

+  it('dumps strings with escaped slash', function()
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/')]]))
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/', {})]]))
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/', { __invalid_key = true })]]))
+    eq('"Test\\/"', exec_lua([[return vim.json.encode('Test/', { escape_forward_slash = true })]]))

comment_regular_data.body: can `escape_forward_slash=false` be the new default? I thought we were encoding JSON, not JSON-embedded-inside-html. Would LSP servers break if we just send them JSON?

This seems good, and +1 for making it the default (mention this in news.txt).

As a followup, we also need help with merging upstream changes, e.g.: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24070#issuecomment-1598366646

> can `escape_forward_slash=false` be the new default? I thought we were encoding JSON, not JSON-embedded-inside-html. Would LSP servers break if we just send them JSON?

I would definitely be in favor of that, I have never seen an implementation of JSON that escapes those (except PHP that does it because it was designed to primarily output to HTML). Even JS does not do that.

So, do we keep the option and just set it to `false` by default? Or do we just drop it, and switch it globally?

> So, do we keep the option and just set it to `false` by default?

👍 I didn't look closely, but if you found a good pattern for supporting options in a non-global way, then that seems useful for possibly supporting other options in the future. For reference, we  [removed the cjson global options](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24070).

> 👍 I didn't look closely, but if you found a good pattern for supporting options in a non-global way, then that seems useful for possibly supporting other options in the future. For reference, we [removed the cjson global options](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24070).

Yeah, sure, the only reason for this diff being so long is the addition of `json_encode_options_t` that is available in the whole encode call stack for easy addition of new options in the future.

I believe the comments are addressed, and no escape is now the default.
The failed CI step seems to be a flake?

> would you mind rebasing this

should be good now

title: feat(json): `escape_slash` encoding option
